text: <@U3JBD4XM3|sjthn> has joined the channel
hey guys
Hello!

What is your approach to show the user an error (dialog) when there is no connection? I usually wait for a call to the API to fail, verify if that error is due to loss of connection and then show the user the error.
Definitely not a popup for me
I try to have as a few popups as possible
I think its best just to show banner to relevant places in your UI
Like your internet connection is lost on a light-yellow banner
with an X button
or you can use Snackbar
with Retry Connection action or something
Sure, thats definitely  better but my point is not the UI point of view, it's the logic behind it :stuck_out_tongue:
oooh

It depends on where the user are at the app. If the user is at a [login screen]. I prefer to show a popup when they click login. This will call the user to action to fix his problem.

If the use is already logged in. Then i rather show a banner “No connection"
Ok but how do you know you need to show the banner: "No connection"
I thought otherwise
It's only when a call to the API is made, or you have a service checking your connectivity to internet
I separate authentication activity with the rest
what are you using?
I use retrofit
retrofit 2
it has onFailure callback
that is the part where I handle recall api or banner show etc.
I have used tons of different. Work as a consultant. But my private app are using retrofit and firebase
Yes so basically you are checking the error retrofit sends and show the no connectivity banner
I send failure to my wrapper that will handle it accordingly
Thats how I usually do it as well
yeah
the function name says what it should do anyway so we just fill in the blanks
public void onFailure(Call<> call, Throwable t)
cause I was thinking if I could find out -before- making the api call
You can always check the state of connectivity
yeah
yes but for that I would need a service continuously checking for it
like using broadcast receiver?

like listening to the state of connectivity, it doesn't really check it all the time, the OS will throw a signal that the connection was on/off, you listen to this (filtering it out) and act accordingly.
although I haven't done this on most of my projects
yeah
Like so
alright maybe I am misunderstanding your requirements
what are you doing?
You were right about the broadcast receiver
this is what I  want :slightly_smiling_face:
Totally forgot about this
alright I hope that helps
let us know if it works on you as intended, otherwise you can always chat here and maybe we can help :smile:
and I even have the context there to inject stuff:)
<@U379MC1E0>: <@U3E2EEX38> Kotlin isn't converted to Java. It's converted to JVM bytecode just like Java and Groovy.
oh

I have enabled both Google Places Web API and Google Places Android API in my Google Developers Console
